Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2011 02:14PM LaurenCollins wrote: Hi Karen and blessings20, I am having either a uni or bilateral mast on Nov. 14, and I can't decide which to do.  I lean more toward haveing a BMX for the peace of mind and symmetry of it all.  I am 36 with two very young children and a very supportive husband.  My mom is a 10 year survivor dx at age 51 but she had a lumpectomy, rad and tamoxifen.  She thikns I should have a uni mast because she thinks losing feeling is a bad option.  I'm toran as to what to do.  I will definitely have immediate reconstruction, probably with tissue expanders at the tie of surgery.  I am also a B cup, used to be a good C before my babies, so the thought of nice perky boobs sounds like the only positive to this whole mess.  Any thoughts?  Glad to know others are out there waiting too. So hard to not know what to do.  I go see my PS on Tuesday and hope to have more answers then. Lauren

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 09:16PM LaurenCollins wrote: Hi ladies, I just wanted to post to all of you that I decided to do a BMX.  It was a difficult choice, but I am feeling good about it being the right choice.  I am getting nervous, sad and anxious to have it done next Monday (nov. 14).  I keep trying to remind myself how lucky I am that this was found early (and I hope that they do not find anything else when they do pathology on the breast tissue and nodes), that I can possibly have this surgery and reconstruction and put it all behind me (no treatments, I hope), that i can possibly still look and feel good about myself and body with reconstruction, and that I will hopefully go on to live a long life.  In 5 years this will be a bump in the road that is in my rear-view mirror.   I will try to post post-BMX for those of you who are having surgery in Dec so I can be of any help on what it is like.   Best wishes to everyone, Lauren

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2011 02:47PM LaurenCollins wrote: CarolAnn6 -- I really feel for you and your tough decision.  I just had to make a similar decison in November.  Try to take time to think rationally about it, make a pros/cons sheet, talk to as many people as you can about their experiences, and at the end go with your gut.  Try to make your decision a few days or a week before your surgery so you can really live with your decision before you go in.  You need to be confident in your decision, it's just too big of one not to know what you want.   I can tell you that my mom is a brest cancer survivor, and although I do not have the BRCA gene, I am young-ish (36 with 2 young children), so knew that I wanted all of this BC stuff behind me.  I did not like the 20% chance of recurrence in other breast.  I do miss feeling, alot, mostly in being able to hug, play, etc with my kids.  I think it will come back and I will feel a new sense of normalcy with my new foobs one day, just not yet.   I hope you get all the info and support you need to make the best decision for you.
